coredata.dc:title: A working procedure for the evaluation of exafs phase shifts: Application to Cu(111)/Cs
coredata.dc:creator: Paul, J.
Lundberg, M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A theoretical procedure is presented to evaluate EXAFS phase shifts. The procedure is based on a self-consistently determined ground-state electron density and an energy-dependent complex scattering potential. Most EXAFS or NEXAFS/XANES schemes used today apply a constant imaginary part of the scattering potential. We illustrate our procedure by calculations on cesium atoms adsorbed onto Cu(111).

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 117, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 28 June 1985 A WORKING PROCEDURE FOR THE EVALUATION OF EXAFS PHASE SHIFTS: APPLICATION TO Cu(lll)/Cs J. PAUL' Department of Physics. Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Goteborg. Sweden and M. LUNDBERO Department of Theoretical Physics. Royal Institute of Technology, S-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden Received 5 March 1985; in final form 1 May 1985 A theoretical procedure is presented to evaluate EXAFS phase shifts The procedure is based on a self-consislemly determined ground-stale electron density and an energy-dependent complex scaltering polsniial- Most EXAFS or NEXAFS/XANES schemes used today apply a consLanI imaginary pan of the scattering potential We illustrate our procedure by calculations on cesium atoms adsorbed onto Cu(Ill). "Peeling the EXAFS (extended X-ray absorption fine structure) onion", i.e. the process of evaluating bond lengths from the oscillatory part of the absorp- tion cross section above threshold energy of a core excitation, demands the knowledge of scattering phase shifts of single atoms or pairs of atoms [1]. Such phase shifts are normally derived from EXAFS measurements on model compounds of known structures, relying on the transferability of these data [2]. Even if a model compound does exist problems may still arise when the valence electron distribution dif- fers to much between model and "hot" compounds or from interfering pairs of scattering atoms in the model compound: The application of scattering data taken from ab initio calculations on free atoms [3] has only been qualitatively successful, thus to our mind illustrating the difficulty of transferability. Instead, we suggest a theoretical approach based on a three-step procedure: (i) Calculation of the self-consistent electronic 1 ' Present address' Exxon Research and Engineering Company, • Clinton --Township; Route" 22 East, Annandale, NJ 08801, USA. 0 009-2614/85/S 03.30 © Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) structure either for the neutral ground state, i.e. the LEED (low-energy electron diffraction) case (A), for the unrelaxed core hole (B), or for the completely relaxed core hold (C).. (h) Derivation of an energy-dependent excited state potential from the self-consistent electron density. (iii) Evaluation of phase shifts from mufiin-tin potentials adjusted to the molecular potential. Step (i) is achieved in an all-electron Xa LCAO cluster approach. We use a discrete variational method (DVM) scheme [4], which enables calculations to be made in any geometry and with any basis functions. However unknown at this stage we have to assume a geometry at step (i). This assumption can be tested for self-consistency in pair with the outcome of an EXAFS evaluation process following step (iii). The choice of potential (A—C) in step (i) relates to the degree of screening [5]. We figure that the most reliable test of the choice of potential as well as of our entire procedure is to set it at work in an EXAFS scheme and judge its capability from the outcome. An analogous scheme for LEED phase shifts has proven valuable [6]. 511 Volume 117, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 28 June 1985 In this communication we illustrate the procedure by calculations on cesium atoms adsorbed onto a Cu(l 11) surface. This system has the advantage that a LEED analysis has been performed [7] and EXAFS measurements are in progress [8]. We use a model with one cesium atom terminally adsorbed 5.69 au above a cluster of seven copper atoms As expected, a core hole (Cs 2p) predominantly affects the Cs valence occupation (6s6p) which is enhanced by 0-54 electrons as a result of relaxation Before step (ii), we embed the cluster in its crystal environment. The minimum of the potential in the copper part of the cluster is shifted to fit the inter- stitial potential of copper, —7.5 eV, relative to the Fermi level [9]. For cesium we have used muffin-tin zero V(E, r^^~)=—S.5 eV taken from LEED data [7]. The energy-dependent scattering potential (ii) is calculated by applying the local density theory for the exchange—correlation interaction as outlined by Watson et al. [10]. The excited-state potential is taken as V(E,r)=V^(r)+V^p,p), V^(p. p) + p2 = E + k^(r) + n^(r) , where V-^(r) is the spherically symmetrical Hartree potential, and V^^(p,p) the exchange—correlation excitation potential, ky(r') is the local Femu mo- mentum, ^xcW the local chemical potential and p the spherically symmetrical electron density. i^xcO». p) is tabulated by Hodin and Lundqvist [11]- An energy-dependent imaginary potential based on LEED data [7], is added to account for the inelastic scattering. Th-i muffin-tin radius of Cs is set to 3.28 au. The phase shifts are evaluated fiom our complex scattering potential by means of numerical integra- tion (fig. 1). The core hole phase shifts (B—C) differs significally from the neutral phase shifts (A) for / = 2, but the relaxed (C) and the unrelaxed core hole (B) phase shifts equal within 0.01 rad. Moreover, the single scattering absorption coefficient X(fc') = S (NJkr2;) u X ImyOr) exp(2iAr„) exp [2i5 ^(fc)] i exp(-2o2*2) 5.0 Fig. 1. The cesium phase shifts for 1=2. The real part (a) and the imaginary part (c) for the relaxed core hole (C) case. and the real part (b) and imaginary part (d) for the neutral (A) for.a p core hole [12] * is calculated ** (fig. 2) to compare to what extent the measurable entity x(k") reflects the phase shift differences, k is the complex wavenumber corresponding to the inner potential, and A:'the common (fic^-.Eo)1^2 [1,12]. The Debye-W"!ier factor 2a2 equals 0.022 au [14].A^„ is the number of atoms with the distance r„ to the central atom./Or) is the backscattering amplitude and 52 is the cesium phase shift for 1=2. * For atoms with high atomic numbers the p to s transition is negligible, see ref. [13]. "* For Cs in the terminal site, Cu—Cs = 5.69 au [7]. 0.08 0.01 - 0-00- -0.01 - -0.08 5.0 Fig. 2. The EXAFS function xW tM a Cs p core hole evalu- ated with phase shifts from the neutral cluster (A) Csolid line) and from the core hole cluster (0 (dashed). 512 Volume 117, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 28 June 1985 The merits of the present procedure are the great flexibility to treat any molecule of reasonable size, the energy-dependent excited-state potential [15], and the overall short computational times. The pro- cedure can be refined to include a multipolar expan- sion of the charge density [16], a cyhndrically sym- metric phase shift analysis [17], a lelaavistic scat- tering potential + or at least a spin-Uniestricted cal- culation of the electron density [19], and finally a cluster embedding scheme which does not rely on experimental data [20]. We apply the present ex- presyon for xC^') even in the low-energy regime bearing in mind that this is an approximation. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A theoretical procedure is presented to evaluate EXAFS phase shifts. The procedure is based on a self-consistently determined ground-state electron density and an energy-dependent complex scattering potential. Most EXAFS or NEXAFS/XANES schemes used today apply a constant imaginary part of the scattering potential. We illustrate our procedure by calculations on cesium atoms adsorbed onto Cu(111).
